Property.name: vsync
Property.HelpText:
The target framerate the game should aim for. Lower values will be easier to run and more stable on lower-end hardware, at the cost of a smoother gameplay experience.
Certain animations, such as those in menus, are tied to the framerate and will play at a slower speed at lower fps values.

Property.name: anisotropy
Property.HelpText:
Sharpens the appearance of textures at acute/sharp viewing angles. Dreamcast called this 'Supersampling'.
Auto: Allow the game itself to define when anisotropic filtering is used, matching Dreamcast. x## : Force a specific level of anisotropic filtering on all textures.

Property.name: texfilter
Property.HelpText:
How textures should be upscaled/downscaled on the screen.
Auto: Allow the game itself to define what filtering is used, matching Dreamcast.
Point: Force point sampling, this is also called 'Nearest Neighbor'.
Bilinear: Force bilinear filtering, which is smooth/blurry.
Trilinear: Force trilinear filtering, which is the same as bilinear but also filters mipmap levels.

Property.name: mipdadj
Property.HelpText:
Adjusts when texture mipmap levels are used. Lower values give the game a sharper look, while higher values give the game a softer look.
Clamp: Force mipmap adjust value to within (min~max)
Auto: Allow the game itself to define what mipmap adjust is used, matching Dreamcast.
0.50: Mipmaps are 2x further away. 1.00: Mipmaps are used normally. 2.00: Mipmaps are 2x closer. Etc...

Property.name: mipmaps
Property.HelpText:
If texture mipmaps should be used.
Mipmaps are lower resolution duplicates of a texture that are used at further distances. Disabling this gives the game a very sharp look at the cost of being very harsh on the eyes.
Only recommended for very specific reasons or with the use of antialiasing, like supersampling.

Property.name: gidx_ignore
Property.HelpText: Forces the game to ignore the Global Index value for textures, which fixes some texture issues at the cost of some memory.

Property.name: mod_shadow
Property.HelpText:
Modifier shadows, also known as Dreamcast shadows, use volume models for shadowing instead of textures. This also restores many shadows that were lost after the Dreamcast version.
'Performance' reduces the number of draw calls at the cost of some accuracy.

Property.name: cnk_spec
Property.HelpText: Specular highlights are the bright spots on models where lighting is most direct/intense, giving those areas a shiny look. This was used heavily in the Dreamcast version but was lost in the Battle ports of the game.

Property.name: kanji
Property.HelpText: Font to be used when displaying Japanese text, such as: Kanji (漢字), Hiragana (ひらがな), and Katakana (カタカナ).

Property.name: ascii
Property.HelpText: Font to be used when displaying Latin text, such as: English, German, French, Spanish, and Italian.

Property.name: width
Property.HelpText:
Change the spacing between each character. Custom fonts can override this option if they wish.
'Auto' will set the spacing based on your choice of font. Eg. 'Comic Sans' will use 'Comfy'.
The original (DC/GC) games used 'Comfy', the HD ports use 'Squished'.

Property.name: space
Property.HelpText:
Change the width of the space character. Custom fonts can override this option if they wish.
'Auto' will set the spacing based on your choice of font. Eg. 'Comic Sans' will use 'Half Width'.
The original (DC/GC) games used 'Half Width', the HD ports use 'Third Width'.

Property.name: ptfilter
Property.HelpText:
Use point sampling on the font textures, same as the Dreamcast version.
NOTE: This is enabled automatically when playing in 480p resolution.

Property.name: model
Property.HelpText:
If the player characters should use their original Dreamcast models, or their Battle models.
Dreamcast models have been ported as-is with no changes, excluding Chaos 0 who had his inner and outer layers seperated.
GameCube models have had a number of fixes applied, mostly incorrect material flags.
Dark Chao Walker is currently unaffected by this setting.

Property.name: lod_mdl
Property.HelpText: If the LOD (Level Of Detail) player models should be used, and when.

Property.name: chaos0_texanim
Property.HelpText:
If Chaos 0 should cycle through his water textures.
This animation was not present in the Dreamcast version, but Render Fix *does* support using the it on the Dreamcast model. If this is enabled, however, he will use the GameCube textures instead of his original Dreamcast ones.

Property.name: shadow_lightdash
Property.HelpText: Unlike Sonic, Shadow lacks a lightdash after-image effect in all release versions. This restores the unused effect by adding logic to handle Shadow, which the devs forgot.

Property.name: miles_tailmod
Property.HelpText:
Draw modifier shadows for Tails' Tails, that otherwise lack them.
This is a Render Fix exclusive enhancement, and was not present on the original Dreamcast version.

Property.name: twalk_footmod
Property.HelpText:
Fix the Tornado Walker's foot shadows drawing underground when stood still. This simply raises the shadows slightly to avoid the issue.
This is a Render Fix exclusive fix, and the bug was present on the original Dreamcast version.

Property.name: shadow_md
Property.HelpText:
Which shadow type is cast by the player character.
'Modifier' is the Dreamcast shadow system, and the recommended setting.
'Enhanced' is the vanilla shadow system, but uses the main model and draws player equipment.
Active development and support for the vanilla shadow system has ended, and it may be removed in the future.

Property.name: mdl_shadow
Property.HelpText:
Enable/Disable modifier shadows displaying on character models. On Dreamcast, this is a feature but here you can disable it if it's not for your taste.
Disabling this may cause player characters to look out of place in some situations.

Property.name: trans_sorting
Property.HelpText: Fixes and restores many common missing transparancy effects and transparancy sorting issues found throughout the game.

Property.name: e_emblem
Property.HelpText: Fixes the draw order of GUN enemies so their emblems render correctly.

Property.name: e_ai_shield
Property.HelpText: Restores the Dreamcast's version of the Hunter's Shield, which looks noticeably less broken.

Property.name: e_stg_tex
Property.HelpText: Restores enemy textures that were specific to some stages in the Dreamcast version.

Property.name: IncludeDir0
Property.HelpText:
Which version of the Events should be used.
Render Fix Enhanced: Enhanced versions of the original Dreamcast events, fixing oversights, timing issues, and backporting a few improvements Battle made.
Dreamcast: Pure ports of the Dreamcast events, as they originally appeared in 2001.

Property.name: vsync_mode
Property.HelpText:
Change the framerate of Events.
On Dreamcast, the Event itself decided when 30FPS would be used. This feature removed for Battle, and all ran at 60FPS no matter what.
If you're having trouble running the Events, setting them to always run at 30FPS might help.
NOTE: Requires 'RF's Event Renderer' to take effect.

Property.name: draw_equip
Property.HelpText:
Draw player upgrades/equipment in events.
NOTE: Requires 'RF's Event Renderer' to take effect.

Property.name: 43_mode
Property.HelpText:
Force the events into their original aspect ratio - covering up many issues that the player was never intended to see.
Always: Use pillar boxes on all events/cutscenes. Exclude Intro: 'Always', but excluding the Dreamcast intro. Conservative: Use pillar boxes only when absolutely necessary to hide issues. Never: No events will use pillar boxes, issues or not.
NOTE: Requires 'RF's Event Renderer' to take effect.

Property.name: overlay_fit
Property.HelpText:
How the overlay video effects will be fit to the screen.
Fit: Keep the video in 4:3, do nothing. Stretch: Stretch video to fill the screen. Clamp: Stretch only outer video pixels to fill the screen. Mirror: Mirror video on each side. Crop: Crop the upper and lower sections of the video.
Note: Has no effect when Event is forced into 4:3.

Property.name: movie_fit
Property.HelpText:
How the FMV/Movie videos will be fit to the screen.
Fit: Keep the video in 4:3, do nothing. Stretch: Stretch video to fill the screen. Clamp: Stretch only outer video pixels to fill the screen. Mirror: Mirror video on each side. Crop: Crop the upper and lower sections of the video.

Property.name: murky
Property.HelpText: Restores the murky water effect that was massively toned down in the GameCube version.

Property.name: kanban
Property.HelpText: Restores the roadside posters from the Dreamcast and GameCube versions.

Property.name: cart_sprite
Property.HelpText: The cart models were lowered for Battle, but the cart headlight sprites were not. This lowers the sprites to fix the visual desync. The 'Dreamcast' option instead raises the cart to the sprites to match the Dreamcast version.

Property.name: zanki
Property.HelpText: The zanki icon, the head sprite that appears next to your lives, is drawn too high in the HD versions. This option lowers it to its correct height, as seen on Dreamcast and GameCube.

Property.name: ptcl_poly_scl
Property.HelpText: Change the size of polygon particles. The scale value is in 480p pixels, aka (pixel_scale * (vertical_resolution / 480p)) or (8 * (1080p / 480p)). NOTE: requires 'Fix Particle Scale'.

Property.name: race_tree_mod
Property.HelpText: Adds modifier shadows for Chao Race Trees which normally don't have any, even on Dreamcast.

Property.name: pause_font_col
Property.HelpText: Which colors should be used for the pause menu text.

Property.name: dc_ring
Property.HelpText:
Enable the black ring shadows from the Dreamcast version.
The black shadows were a deliberate choice made to make the rings easier to see, but the code was lost when porting to Battle.

Property.name: shadow_res
Property.HelpText:
Changes the resolution of the texture used by shadow maps.
Higher values lead to less pixelated shadow maps at the cost of memory and performance, lower values the opposite.
Shadow maps are no longer actively supported, and may be removed in the future.

Property.name: no_shadows
Property.HelpText: Disable all game shadows, modifier or shadow map.

Property.name: uifilter
Property.HelpText: Use point sampling on some UI textures, such as the in-game HUD, to match the Dreamcast version.

Property.name: dc_menu_fade
Property.HelpText: This re-enables fading effects for the Dreamcast main menu background, however causes it to draw much darker than intended.

Property.name: pl_brokenfix
Property.HelpText:
Disables new rendering features for player models to hide issues such as broken surface normals and incorrectly set material flags; causing holes, extremely dark lighting, etc.
Older mods were unaware they had these issues, so couldn't fix them. This should mostly restore the vanilla environment.
[ WARNING! ] Don't enable this for no reason! Many newer mods require these features and won't work correctly without them!

Property.name: pl_texmat
Property.HelpText:
Reenables diffuse material color on player character models as some mods - but not many - require it to work correctly.
[ WARNING! ] Don't enable this for no reason! Many models will actually break with this enabled, including RF's 'Dreamcast Character Models'!

Property.name: chw_mod
Property.HelpText:
Disables RF's Modifier Shadows in Chao World for compatibility with Chao mods that have their own shadow systems. Older mods can't do this on their own, but newer mods should enable this for you when needed.
[ WARNING! ] Don't enable this for no reason! Only enable if another mod will actually apply a new shadow system to Chao World!

Property.name: old_atest
Property.HelpText:
Use pre-1.4 alpha test parameters, which may fix some graphical oddities with transparent objects while re-introducing vanilla ones.
[ WARNING! ] Don't enable this for no reason!

Property.name: frametime_info
Property.HelpText:
Display frametime information on-screen to easily track game performance.
IMM: Value from *this* frame. AVG: Average over a few seconds. TGT: Target being aimed for.
FPS: Theoretical FPS value. FMS: Frametime in milliseconds.

Property.name: extra_info
Property.HelpText: Print additional debug info into the game console. This is useful for getting very in-depth information on what Render Fix is doing internally.

Property.name: event
Property.HelpText:
Enable Render Fix's Event debug functions: X - Free-Cam - Analog sticks to move & look, up/down dpad to zoom in/out, left/right dpad to roll. Y - Scrubbing - The triggers are fine controls, the shoulders skip scenes. B - Layer Viewer - Pressing B multiple times will switch draw layers.
Back - Display Event debug info.

Property.name: modifier
Property.HelpText: Draws modifier models directly to screen, rather than treating them as volumes for shadows. Useful for debugging modifier models in-game.

Property.name: maxmiplev
Property.HelpText:
Restrict the texture mipmaps to a maximum mip level; with '0' meaning the full texture, '1' meaning the first mipmap, etc.
If a mipmap of the selected level isn't available, the next highest mipmap is used (eg. setting is '9' and there's only '7' mip levels, '7' is used).
This can be used to view and test your mipmaps without needing to pull out a magnifying glass.

Property.name: no_alerts
Property.HelpText:
Disable Render Fix alert/warning message boxes, such as mod position and conflict warnings.
This is at your own risk, these warnings exist for a reason!

Property.name: game_speed
Property.HelpText:
Changes the game speed by always forcing a set number of skipped frames. This setting has no effect on most menu elements.
This is useful for modders who wish to stress test their code over long periods, but be aware that display code is still only called 60x per second.
